PRIZE TO BE GIVEN
FOR GETTING WOOD
The Sophomore Pep Committee announced Saturday
that a prize of five dollars
will be awarded to the freshman who secures the largest
number Of boxes for the annual St. John's bonfire Friday night.
The committee has also
announced that tags similar
to those used for the football
games will be printed and
distributed to any freshman
who helps secure wood.
Freshmen who do not have
these tags by the middle of
the week will be dealt with
by the Pep Committee.

Parliament Member To
Talk Here Tomorrow
The Hon. Ramsay Muir, former
member of Parliament, and an authority in political science, will deliver at five o'clock tomorrow afternoon in the Civil Engineering Building 'a lecture on "The Decline of
Parliamentary Government."
Dr. Muir has done much work,
not only in the practical but also in
the theoretical side of politics, being editor of the Weekly Westminster magazine. From 1913 to 1921
he was professor of modern history
at Owens College, Manchester. He
served on the Calcutta University
commission from 1917-19. He has,
moreover, written a number of
books which deal with the important political problems of the present time.

COLLEGE MEN IGNORANT
OF LAW, SAYS DR.
OLIVER
Students of University of Vienna, However, Study Criminology as
Part of Curriculum

"College men on the whole are
ignorant of the law," declared Dr.
John R. Oliver, psychiatrist of the
Baltimore Police Department and
Medical Officer of the Baltimore
Supreme.Bench, speaking on the
subject of "Criminals, Murderers
and Detective's" at last Thursday's
assembly.
Little contact with the law, and
that limited to the traffic court,
was the reason Dr. Oliver gave
for this assertion. He said that it
is really pitiful to see the utter ignorance of the law evidenced by
those who received the call for
jury duty and other court work.
The remedy is positive: citizens
should arrange at frequent intervals to stop at the Courthouse to
get an insight on practical court
proceedings. The psychiatrist
urged Hopkins students especially
to take a trip to the Courthouse,
promising personally to conduct
and introduce them to actual court
proceedings.
Types of Criminals

Dr. Oliver discussed the various
types of criminal's. The murderer
isn't really a criminal at all, he
said. He is a man who has made
a mistake and pays for it the rest
of his life. He is the victim of
fate, which brings together simultaneously the elements of hate,
anger, gun, and man.
The criminal is no different
from anyone else. He gets into a
jam and is simply too weak to get
out of it. The worst type of criminal is the confidence man, the scurrile thief who, undergoing no danger to himself, lives on deceit,
wrecking lives, and ruining life
plans. This man gets a short sentence, gets out, and does the same
thing over again.
Then there is the new type of
holdup man, who looks like any
undergraduate in college. He is
the , nerveless kind whose gun
shakes in his hand. People should
not submit docilely to such a man.
AS cuff will send him scurrying.
Finally, there is the organized
class of criminal which makes
crime a profession. He hasn't the
slightest regard for human life.
Dr. Oliver set forth the notorious
Whittemore as an example. For

It's hard to realize how quickly time passes. Next Friday
night we'll be burning old St. John's again, but according to Bob
Burnett, it won't be necessary to resort to strategic arson to do it.
Congratulations, Bob! Well, in spite of all Mr. Paul Menton et
al. can say about how badly Loyola beat us, we still will probably
be able to sing "Oh where, oh where, are the soldier boys" this
year. From all we hear from the sports department, Hopkins
should do considerably better than a seven to seven tie. IVIais
nous verrons.

We just can't stop thinking about the blushing beauties,
though. Here's our latest kick. Why is it that our juniors and
underclassmen are not allowed "the privileges of the Gilman
Memorial Room-; when any wanton female freshman may stroll
up and down the secret passageway leading from the Memorial
Room to the Library whenever the stimuli to her neural transits
so direct? It's wrong, we say, all wrong. Why, instead of persecuting poor freshmen who violate a tradition or two, can't the
Student Council try to abolish this substitution of license for liberty? We want to know.

IMMEDIATE ACTION REQUIRED
The Randolph-Macon game, so successful in all other respects, was marred by one of the most unfortunate spectacles ever
witnessed at Homewood Field—a fight between two Hopkins students. The affair was deplorable from every angle. It is the first
time in several years that the unwritten rule against bad feeling
in freshman-sophomore clashes has been broken to any serious
extent. Far worse than that, the fight occurred at a time when
the University was, in a sense of the word, on exhibition before
the public. About half the crowd, which included many outsiders,
witnessed the episode, and doubtless did not carry away any
heightened impression of the University.
At the time of writing we do not know any of the details
of the combat; we are not especially interested. Very probably
neither of the men deserves any more blame than the other. The
sophomore, beyond question, believed that he was carrying out
his duty, and he was. In the past regulations had always been
enforced at games, why should they not continue to be enforced?
The freshman, with an equal show of reason, resisted the strongarm methods of the sophs. No man wants to be humiliated before a crowd of two thousand people. The resulting fight was
unquestionably disgraceful, but not all of the blame can be laid
upon either of the principals. They were to some extent the victims of circumstance; the system itself is at fault.
It is remarkable that no serious trouble has occurred before.
Football games are not the place to enforce regulations. Outsiders who come to the games pay their admission to see a football game, not to watch the punishment of unruly freshmen.
Many of them do not understand what such occasions mean; they
never heard of regulations or have the slightest inkling of their
significance. Naturally they look upon the activities of the Pep
Committee as pure rowdyism. Also, from the point of view of a
freshman punishment which under ordinary conditions would be
accepted as just becomes ten times as bitter when administered
before a large audience.
We do not mean that regulations should not be in effect during games, but merely that they should not be enforced there.
The Pep Committee could very easily make out a list of all freshmen ,breaking regulations. These offenders could be summoned
at the beginning of the next week, perhaps a double share of punishment should be meted out to them. At all events, however,
some method must be adopted to remove the necessity of washing
our dirty linen in public.

As you have probably guessed by this time, we think we are
a very bored, sophisticated, thrilless undergrad, but we received
what we consider the supreme thrill a few evenings ago while
supping at the Barn. We were sitting at a table by ourselves,
musing aimlessly and deeply absorbed in fantastic reverie when
we were rudely interrupted by a female voice from behind piping,
"Vernon, who is this D. H. M.?" "I don't know," he replied.
"Well, I'd like to meet him." Just at that moment Doc Adams
turned on that infernal carbonizer of his, and the remainder of
the conversation was lost.
It took all of the will power. that Mr. Schopenhauer might
have given us credit for to refrain from jumping up and shouting ecstatically, "Behold, here am I!" Wright can have his airplane, Edison his incandescent bulb, Biddison his touchdown
against Penn, and Mullikin his Conowingo, but none can compare
with the golden glow that we felt for a week after that conversation.
Once more. We hate to put ourselves in the light of an
eavesdropper, but a conversation we happened to overhear one
evening while returning via United Railways from Dr. Boas's
lecture on French Philosophy of the Nineteenth Century is just
a bit too typical to leave unprinted. Again the conversationalist
was a female. "You know," she said, "sometimes I could just kick
that horrid Doctor Boazz on the shins
but he's such a dear !"

Detective Systems

Dr. Oliver completed his speech
with a comparison of American
and European detective systems.
Only in France, he said, does the
detective work singly. In America
and England and Germany criminals are brought to justice by
hard work and by team work. Six
to eight detectives work in a
group. In shadowing, three officers work on one man, interchanging to avoid suspicion.
In Berlin, concluded Dr. Oliver,
every newcomer is catalogued for
identification. Unique indexes are
kept in the German metropolis,
classification's having such headings as "red hair," "limping left
leg," and other physical characteristics.

PRIZE TO BE GIVEN
FOR GETTING WOOD
The Sophomore Pep Committee announced Saturday
that a prize of five dollars
will be awarded to the freshman who secures the largest
number Of boxes for the annual St. John's bonfire Friday night.
The committee has also
announced that tags similar
to those used for the football
games will be printed and
distributed to any freshman
who helps secure wood.
Freshmen who do not have
these tags by the middle of
the week will be dealt with
by the Pep Committee.

Parliament Member To
Talk Here Tomorrow
The Hon. Ramsay Muir, former
member of Parliament, and an authority in political science, will deliver at five o'clock tomorrow afternoon in the Civil Engineering Building 'a lecture on "The Decline of
Parliamentary Government."
Dr. Muir has done much work,
not only in the practical but also in
the theoretical side of politics, being editor of the Weekly Westminster magazine. From 1913 to 1921
he was professor of modern history
at Owens College, Manchester. He
served on the Calcutta University
commission from 1917-19. He has,
moreover, written a number of
books which deal with the important political problems of the present time.

COLLEGE MEN IGNORANT
OF LAW, SAYS DR.
OLIVER
Students of University of Vienna, However, Study Criminology as
Part of Curriculum

"College men on the whole are
ignorant of the law," declared Dr.
John R. Oliver, psychiatrist of the
Baltimore Police Department and
Medical Officer of the Baltimore
Supreme.Bench, speaking on the
subject of "Criminals, Murderers
and Detective's" at last Thursday's
assembly.
Little contact with the law, and
that limited to the traffic court,
was the reason Dr. Oliver gave
for this assertion. He said that it
is really pitiful to see the utter ignorance of the law evidenced by
those who received the call for
jury duty and other court work.
The remedy is positive: citizens
should arrange at frequent intervals to stop at the Courthouse to
get an insight on practical court
proceedings. The psychiatrist
urged Hopkins students especially
to take a trip to the Courthouse,
promising personally to conduct
and introduce them to actual court
proceedings.
Types of Criminals

Dr. Oliver discussed the various
types of criminal's. The murderer
isn't really a criminal at all, he
said. He is a man who has made
a mistake and pays for it the rest
of his life. He is the victim of
fate, which brings together simultaneously the elements of hate,
anger, gun, and man.
The criminal is no different
from anyone else. He gets into a
jam and is simply too weak to get
out of it. The worst type of criminal is the confidence man, the scurrile thief who, undergoing no danger to himself, lives on deceit,
wrecking lives, and ruining life
plans. This man gets a short sentence, gets out, and does the same
thing over again.
Then there is the new type of
holdup man, who looks like any
undergraduate in college. He is
the , nerveless kind whose gun
shakes in his hand. People should
not submit docilely to such a man.
AS cuff will send him scurrying.
Finally, there is the organized
class of criminal which makes
crime a profession. He hasn't the
slightest regard for human life.
Dr. Oliver set forth the notorious
Whittemore as an example. For

It's hard to realize how quickly time passes. Next Friday
night we'll be burning old St. John's again, but according to Bob
Burnett, it won't be necessary to resort to strategic arson to do it.
Congratulations, Bob! Well, in spite of all Mr. Paul Menton et
al. can say about how badly Loyola beat us, we still will probably
be able to sing "Oh where, oh where, are the soldier boys" this
year. From all we hear from the sports department, Hopkins
should do considerably better than a seven to seven tie. IVIais
nous verrons.

We just can't stop thinking about the blushing beauties,
though. Here's our latest kick. Why is it that our juniors and
underclassmen are not allowed "the privileges of the Gilman
Memorial Room-; when any wanton female freshman may stroll
up and down the secret passageway leading from the Memorial
Room to the Library whenever the stimuli to her neural transits
so direct? It's wrong, we say, all wrong. Why, instead of persecuting poor freshmen who violate a tradition or two, can't the
Student Council try to abolish this substitution of license for liberty? We want to know.

IMMEDIATE ACTION REQUIRED
The Randolph-Macon game, so successful in all other respects, was marred by one of the most unfortunate spectacles ever
witnessed at Homewood Field—a fight between two Hopkins students. The affair was deplorable from every angle. It is the first
time in several years that the unwritten rule against bad feeling
in freshman-sophomore clashes has been broken to any serious
extent. Far worse than that, the fight occurred at a time when
the University was, in a sense of the word, on exhibition before
the public. About half the crowd, which included many outsiders,
witnessed the episode, and doubtless did not carry away any
heightened impression of the University.
At the time of writing we do not know any of the details
of the combat; we are not especially interested. Very probably
neither of the men deserves any more blame than the other. The
sophomore, beyond question, believed that he was carrying out
his duty, and he was. In the past regulations had always been
enforced at games, why should they not continue to be enforced?
The freshman, with an equal show of reason, resisted the strongarm methods of the sophs. No man wants to be humiliated before a crowd of two thousand people. The resulting fight was
unquestionably disgraceful, but not all of the blame can be laid
upon either of the principals. They were to some extent the victims of circumstance; the system itself is at fault.
It is remarkable that no serious trouble has occurred before.
Football games are not the place to enforce regulations. Outsiders who come to the games pay their admission to see a football game, not to watch the punishment of unruly freshmen.
Many of them do not understand what such occasions mean; they
never heard of regulations or have the slightest inkling of their
significance. Naturally they look upon the activities of the Pep
Committee as pure rowdyism. Also, from the point of view of a
freshman punishment which under ordinary conditions would be
accepted as just becomes ten times as bitter when administered
before a large audience.
We do not mean that regulations should not be in effect during games, but merely that they should not be enforced there.
The Pep Committee could very easily make out a list of all freshmen ,breaking regulations. These offenders could be summoned
at the beginning of the next week, perhaps a double share of punishment should be meted out to them. At all events, however,
some method must be adopted to remove the necessity of washing
our dirty linen in public.

As you have probably guessed by this time, we think we are
a very bored, sophisticated, thrilless undergrad, but we received
what we consider the supreme thrill a few evenings ago while
supping at the Barn. We were sitting at a table by ourselves,
musing aimlessly and deeply absorbed in fantastic reverie when
we were rudely interrupted by a female voice from behind piping,
"Vernon, who is this D. H. M.?" "I don't know," he replied.
"Well, I'd like to meet him." Just at that moment Doc Adams
turned on that infernal carbonizer of his, and the remainder of
the conversation was lost.
It took all of the will power. that Mr. Schopenhauer might
have given us credit for to refrain from jumping up and shouting ecstatically, "Behold, here am I!" Wright can have his airplane, Edison his incandescent bulb, Biddison his touchdown
against Penn, and Mullikin his Conowingo, but none can compare
with the golden glow that we felt for a week after that conversation.
Once more. We hate to put ourselves in the light of an
eavesdropper, but a conversation we happened to overhear one
evening while returning via United Railways from Dr. Boas's
lecture on French Philosophy of the Nineteenth Century is just
a bit too typical to leave unprinted. Again the conversationalist
was a female. "You know," she said, "sometimes I could just kick
that horrid Doctor Boazz on the shins
but he's such a dear !"

Detective Systems

Dr. Oliver completed his speech
with a comparison of American
and European detective systems.
Only in France, he said, does the
detective work singly. In America
and England and Germany criminals are brought to justice by
hard work and by team work. Six
to eight detectives work in a
group. In shadowing, three officers work on one man, interchanging to avoid suspicion.
In Berlin, concluded Dr. Oliver,
every newcomer is catalogued for
identification. Unique indexes are
kept in the German metropolis,
classification's having such headings as "red hair," "limping left
leg," and other physical characteristics.
